children: Linear Surrogate is a linear approach to modeling the relationship between a scalar response or dependent variable and one or more explanatory variables. We will use Linear Surrogate to optimize following function:
First of all we have to import these two packages:
We choose to sample f in 20 points between 0 and 10 using the
function. The sampling points are chosen using a Sobol sequence, this can be done by passing

f(x) = sin(x) + log(x)
n_samples = 20
lower_bound = 5.2
upper_bound = 12.5
x = sample(n_samples, lower_bound, upper_bound, SobolSample())
y = f.(x)
scatter(x, y, label="Sampled points", xlims=(lower_bound, upper_bound))
plot!(f, label="True function", xlims=(lower_bound, upper_bound))
With our sampled points we can build the

my_linear_surr_1D = LinearSurrogate(x, y, lower_bound, upper_bound)
add_point!(my_linear_surr_1D,4.0,7.2)
add_point!(my_linear_surr_1D,[5.0,6.0],[8.3,9.7])
val = my_linear_surr_1D(5.0)

plot(x, y, seriestype=:scatter, label="Sampled points", xlims=(lower_bound, upper_bound))
plot!(f, label="True function",  xlims=(lower_bound, upper_bound))
plot!(my_linear_surr_1D, label="Surrogate function",  xlims=(lower_bound, upper_bound))
Having built a surrogate, we can now use it to search for minimas in our original function
To optimize using our surrogate we call
method. We choose to use Stochastic RBF as optimization technique and again Sobol sampling as sampling technique.

@show surrogate_optimize(f, SRBF(), lower_bound, upper_bound, my_linear_surr_1D, SobolSample())
scatter(x, y, label="Sampled points")
plot!(f, label="True function",  xlims=(lower_bound, upper_bound))
plot!(my_linear_surr_1D, label="Surrogate function",  xlims=(lower_bound, upper_bound))
First of all we will define the
function we are going to build surrogate for. Notice, one how its argument is a vector of numbers, one for each coordinate, and its output is a scalar.
Let's define our bounds, this time we are working in two dimensions. In particular we want our first dimension
for the second dimension. We are taking 50 samples of the space using Sobol Sequences. We then evaluate our function on all of the sampling points.

n_samples = 50
lower_bound = [-10.0, 0.0]
upper_bound = [5.0, 15.0]

xys = sample(n_samples, lower_bound, upper_bound, SobolSample())
zs = egg.(xys);

x, y = -10:5, 0:15 # hide
p1 = surface(x, y, (x1,x2) -> egg((x1,x2))) # hide
xs = [xy[1] for xy in xys] # hide
ys = [xy[2] for xy in xys] # hide
scatter!(xs, ys, zs) # hide
p2 = contour(x, y, (x1,x2) -> egg((x1,x2))) # hide
scatter!(xs, ys) # hide
plot(p1, p2, title="True function") # hide
Using the sampled points we build the surrogate, the steps are analogous to the 1-dimensional case.

p1 = surface(x, y, (x, y) -> my_linear_ND([x y])) # hide
scatter!(xs, ys, zs, marker_z=zs) # hide
p2 = contour(x, y, (x, y) -> my_linear_ND([x y])) # hide
scatter!(xs, ys, marker_z=zs) # hide
plot(p1, p2, title="Surrogate") # hide
With our surrogate we can now search for the minimas of the function.
Notice how the new sampled points, which were created during the optimization process, are appended to the
array. This is why its size changes.
surrogate_optimize(egg, SRBF(), lower_bound, upper_bound, my_linear_ND, SobolSample(), maxiters=10)

p1 = surface(x, y, (x, y) -> my_linear_ND([x y])) # hide
xs = [xy[1] for xy in xys] # hide
ys = [xy[2] for xy in xys] # hide
zs = egg.(xys) # hide
scatter!(xs, ys, zs, marker_z=zs) # hide
p2 = contour(x, y, (x, y) -> my_linear_ND([x y])) # hide
scatter!(xs, ys, marker_z=zs) # hide
plot(p1, p2) # hide
